newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybeans end mostly down on short-selling.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybeans end mostly down on short-selling.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended mostly down on Tuesday on short-selling as technical charts showed a downward trend in the short term, traders said.

The most actively traded November 1997 contract closed down at an intraday low of 3,290 yuan ($397) per tonne, down six yuan from Monday's close. It opened higher at 3,320 yuan and dragged down by big shorts.
July rose 40 yuan to 3,290, September fell 48 to 3,296, the January 1998 contract 55 to 3,285 and March rose 43 to 3,300.
Combined volume rose to 19,700 tonnes from 14,600 tonnes.

"After the key November contract fell below the support level of 3,300 yuan yesterday, the charts are plotting are downward track," said one trader. "I believe soybeans will fall further in the next few days."
"Big shorts continued depressing the November and the January 1998 contracts and the enlarged volume indicated more short positions have been built today," another trader said.
Local analysts said they expected the key November contract could find strong support at the 3,250 yuan level on Wednesday.
